title: U.S. Bans Seafood Imports From Chinese Company, Citing Use of Forced Labor
sub_head: It is the latest example of Washington confronting Beijing over human-rights issues
body:
WASHINGTON—The U.S. banned imports of tuna, swordfish and other seafood from a Chinese fishery company, citing evidence of forced labor on its distant-water vessels.
U.S. Customs and Border Protection agents will detain shipments containing seafood harvested by China’s Dalian Ocean Fishing Co., officials said, in the latest example of Washington confronting Beijing over human-rights issues.
“We have found evidence of all 11 forced labor indicators, including physical violence against fishers, debt bondage, withholding of wages and abusive living and working conditions,” Troy Miller, CBP’s senior official performing the duties of the Commissioner, told reporters Friday.
The order applies to the Chinese company’s entire fleet of 32 vessels, which official said operate off the coasts of China, Indonesia and Senegal with mostly Indonesian crews. Canned tuna and pet food containing the company’s products were also banned.
The Chinese Embassy in Washington and Dalian Ocean Fishing, based in China’s northern coastal city of Dalian, didn’t immediately respond to email requests for comment.
